Set Ready For Review
If length <= 8, does it mean no dump content? Can you please add proper message handling in that case?

In the case of 'length <= 8', it indicates that the NC returned a non-zero response code, and an error will have already been returned in the callback function during the previous check. I will add message handling for this case.

As per spec -
0xFFFF0000 Core dump Data Handle used to retrieve core dump
0xFFFF0001 Crash dump Data Handle used to retrieve crash dump

Shouldn't we expose these 2 options in the ncsi-netlink command args rather than hardcoding? How would you handle crashdump otherwise?
Done
Is this a success case and full crash file?
It only means that the NC wants to 'terminate the transfer,' and the NCSI specification doesn't define this part. I believe it depends on the NIC vendor.
Better to call arg this dump-file or dump-file-name, since you are specifying the dump file path for dumping.
Done
Does both dump-file and dump-type needs to be provided, what if just one of the args is provided?
The default ArgumentParser only get one parameter, so i use two args.

I don't see why we should limit to the crash and core dump handlers even if they are the only ones in the 1.2.0 specfication, especially when there are 0xffefffff ids reserved for OEM identified streams.

I think raw netlink packets is the wrong abstraction for NC data block transfers.

Thank you for your feedback. Currently, the design structure follows the OpenBMC NC-SI core dump design guide (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/refs/changes/66/74866/4/designs/ncsi-coredump.md). The use of raw netlink packets was chosen based on this design.

Thank you for your feedback. Currently, the design structure follows the OpenBMC NC-SI core dump design guide (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/refs/changes/66/74866/4/designs/ncsi-coredump.md). The use of raw netlink packets was chosen based on this design. The NC-SI kernel driver provides the "NCSI_CMD_SEND_CMD" interface, which allows a userspace tool to send specific commands.

else if either specified an error?

Why do we have to speify dump-type?   are there future plans?   what purpose is it?

The original design follows DSP0222_1.2.0.pdf Table 228 Data Handle Values. Currently, we only support 'core dump' and 'crash dump'. I will use 'datahandle' as the input argument instead of 'dumptype'. This makes the feature more flexible, and I believe it aligns with your expectations.

There is nothing in the spec aboutthis being a CoreDump packet

Its a NC Data reply packet.
Done

We should be able to transfer any chunk esp any oem by passing the number here (eg atoi()

verify dump type recognized here?  or pass data handle instead of dumpType
I will use 'datahandle' as the input argument instead of 'dumptype'. This makes the feature more flexible, and I believe it aligns with your expectations.

DSP0222 1.2.0 (3688) any multiple of 32 bits (3631) that is RBT frame size.  The total frame 

We core and crash dump we should be saving the last transfer AEN with the handle and total bytes.

As we will  easily wrap the command instance id if we just passed through packets.  If we are already handling them, and there can only be one stream transferred at a time, why not handle the data sequence numbers in the kernel in the NC-SI layer just passing the data stream to across netlink?

Thank you for the input. Here’s how we’re approaching it:

1.32-Bit Padding Compliance: Our implementation ensures that the NC-SI kernel driver automatically pads each packet to align with 32-bit boundaries, per the DSP0222 specification.

2.To clarify, we are specifically implementing the "Receive Data from NC" command (0x4D), which doesn’t directly relate to AEN handling, as AENs are unsolicited notifications rather than data responses to commands. However, we’ll ensure the integrity of received data frames for command 0x4D, as per DSP0222 specifications, while keeping the focus on handling responses in line with this command.

3. Data Sequence Number Management: The "data sequence number" is determined by the "opcode value" in the response packet. Since the packet control encode/decode handler is already located in the ncsi-netlink tool, handling sequence numbers here is both practical and efficient. This approach aligns with the OpenBMC NC-SI core dump design guide (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/refs/changes/66/74866/4/designs/ncsi-coredump.md) and minimizes complexity within the kernel.

4. Streamlining Data Handling in ncsi-netlink: Managing sequence numbers at the ncsi-netlink layer allows for streamlined packet handling and control, consolidating the encoding/decoding responsibilities efficiently within a single layer.
why don't we need the & 0xFF like chunkNum below?
Done

these three items are specific to me transfer 

opcode is set in a reply function without namespace in this class then checked in the namespace outside internal 

this is confusing and creating almost unused State in the middle of the class private to one callback and it's caller

please create a new class for this state
Done

can you decode and log the specific documented causes 
eg sequence error, unknown,
Done
check length is 4 byte aligned or last packet
Done

consider a wrapped callback in a transfer class 

the decode can be in internal get back data and opcode 
the state variables (outfile opcode total written) would be in the transfer class.  this would also be more collected
Done

insufficient checking
  was the whole string processed?
  does the long fit in uint32_t ?
  
wrapping would allow easily recognition of standard names via a comparison loop instead of invoking with the hex number.

place the conversion from string and open the file in caller, 

keep this function in ncsi the state machine

maybe this function takes a process callback that gets the parsed opcode (multiple boolean), payload data and length.
Done

what is internal object?
random class internal?
no it's supposed to be private interfaces not private static variables
Done
let's handle file Io, open and argument parsing in a calling class
Done
it's an error to get a opcode 1 after after the initial transfer or a opcode two in response to the the initial transfer
Done
abort deserves more than a debug message.
Done

sending an abort here.  we are abandoning the transfer

this will avoid a sequence error on retry 

we could also allow the data processing callback to initiate the abort (eg disk full, file not open)
Done
didn't close the internal:outfile
Done
typo ncis
Done
This function is really long. Would it be possible to refactor this switch case into a separate function, lets say, getDescForResponse or similar.
Done
This function is really long. Would it be possible to refactor this switch case into a separate function, lets say, getDescForReason or similar.
Done
This function is really long. Probably break the payload generation into a separate function (such as generateDumpCmdPayload)?
